Award.AwardTitle: IEEE PerCom 2016 Student Travel Support Request

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to provide travel support for the IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications to be held in March 2016 in Sydney, Australia. Louis. The conference includes papers on many technologies that are fundamental to Cyber-Physical Systems specifically, including sensor systems and Internet of Things, as well as the computer and information sciences more broadly. This project will fund 20 students to attend the conference, and a selection committee and process will be used to choose from potential invitees.

The conference will organize a PhD Forum for students and will provide important networking opportunities for the students. The attendance and participation in conference activities including the PhD Forum and student sessions will have strong impact on the education of the next generation of pervasive computing and cyber-physical system experts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications (PerCom) is the flagship conference in the area of pervasive computing (www.percom.org). The 14th edition of the conference IEEE PerCom 2016 was held in Sydney, Australia on March 14-18, 2016; and the 15th edition was held in Big Island, Hawaii on March 13-17, 2017.

Seventeen US-based students were competitively selected for NSF travel grant from this project - twelve of them attended IEEE PerCom 2016 and five students attended IEEE PerCom 2017. They consisted of a first-year postdoc, three undergraduate and two MS students, and the remaining were PhD students from small schools to big name schools. Eight of the selected students were women and three were under-represented minority students.

Intellectual Merit. Papers presented at IEEE PerCom are consistently of very high quality. The acceptance rate is typically below 15%. In addition to the main conference, there were 13 workshops on cutting-edge themes, a PhD Forum, work-in-progress sessions, poster and demo sessions, exciting panels, and two keynote talks. The conference technical program promotes new research directions in pervasive computing including emerging areas like smartphone sensing, crowd sensing, and social networks with applications to cyber-physical-social convergence, smart and connected communities, smart healthcare, internet of things (IoT), security, energy and sustainability.

Broader Impact. Without the NSF travel support, many of the above US-based students would not otherwise be able to attend a top quality conference like IEEE PerCom. Indeed the conference offered valuable opportunity for NSF supported doctoral, masters and undergraduate students to learn about cutting-edge research in pervasive computing, systems and applications that were presented in the main conference and associated events. The NSF travel support not only allowed a greater number of students (including women and underrepresented minority) to attend this flagship conference, but also created an avenue for them to network with the peers and world-class researchers in the field of pervasive computing. This unique opportunity motivated them to do outstanding research by themselves and be successful in academic and industry research careers.
